name: NIST Cybersecurity Framework
description: The NIST Cybersecurity Framework provides a policy framework of computer security guidance for organizations to assess and improve their ability to prevent, detect, and respond to cyber attacks.

framework.name: NIST Cybersecurity Framework
framework.description: Framework for improving critical infrastructure cybersecurity

structure.title: IDENTIFY (ID)
structure.description: Develop organizational understanding to manage cybersecurity risk to systems, people, assets, data, and capabilities

items.title: ID.AM - Asset Management
items.description: The data, personnel, devices, systems, and facilities that enable the organization to achieve business purposes are identified and managed
questions: Is there a complete inventory of physical devices?
Is there an inventory of software platforms and applications?
Are data flows mapped?

items.title: ID.AM-1: Physical devices and systems are inventoried
ID.AM-2: Software platforms and applications are inventoried
ID.AM-3: Organizational communication and data flows are mapped
ID.AM-4: External information systems are catalogued
ID.AM-5: Resources are prioritized based on criticality
ID.RA - Risk Assessment
items.description: The organization understands the cybersecurity risk to organizational operations, assets, and individuals
questions: Are asset vulnerabilities identified and documented?
Is threat intelligence received from information sharing forums?
Are risks determined and prioritized?

items.title: ID.RA-1: Asset vulnerabilities are identified and documented
ID.RA-2: Cyber threat intelligence is received from information sharing forums
ID.RA-3: Threats are identified and documented
ID.RA-4: Potential business impacts and likelihoods are identified
ID.RA-5: Threats, vulnerabilities, likelihoods, and impacts determine risk
ID.GV - Governance
items.description: Policies, procedures, and processes to manage and monitor regulatory, legal, risk, environmental, and operational requirements
questions: Is there an organizational cybersecurity policy?
Are roles and responsibilities coordinated?
Are legal and regulatory requirements understood?

items.title: ID.GV-1: Organizational cybersecurity policy is established
ID.GV-2: Cybersecurity roles and responsibilities are coordinated
ID.GV-3: Legal and regulatory requirements are understood
ID.GV-4: Governance and risk management processes address cybersecurity

structure.title: PROTECT (PR)
structure.description: Develop and implement appropriate safeguards to ensure delivery of critical services

items.title: PR.AC - Access Control
items.description: Access to physical and logical assets and associated facilities is limited to authorized users, processes, and devices
questions: Are identities and credentials managed?
Is physical access to assets managed and protected?
Is remote access managed?

items.title: PR.AC-1: Identities and credentials are issued, managed, verified, revoked
PR.AC-2: Physical access to assets is managed and protected
PR.AC-3: Remote access is managed
PR.AC-4: Access permissions and authorizations are managed
PR.AC-5: Network integrity is protected (segregation, segmentation)
PR.AT - Awareness and Training
items.description: Organization's personnel and partners are provided cybersecurity awareness education
questions: Are all users informed and trained?
Do privileged users understand their responsibilities?
Do third parties understand their responsibilities?

items.title: PR.AT-1: All users are informed and trained
PR.AT-2: Privileged users understand their responsibilities
PR.AT-3: Third-party stakeholders understand their responsibilities
PR.AT-4: Senior executives understand their responsibilities
PR.AT-5: Physical and cybersecurity personnel understand their responsibilities
PR.DS - Data Security
items.description: Information and records are managed consistent with risk strategy to protect confidentiality, integrity, and availability
items.summary: Protect data at rest and in transit
questions: Is data-at-rest protected?
Is data-in-transit protected?
Is data disposed of securely?

items.title: PR.DS-1: Data-at-rest is protected
PR.DS-2: Data-in-transit is protected
PR.DS-3: Assets are formally managed throughout removal, transfers, disposition
PR.DS-4: Adequate capacity to ensure availability is maintained
PR.DS-5: Protections against data leaks are implemented

structure.title: DETECT (DE)
structure.description: Develop and implement appropriate activities to identify the occurrence of a cybersecurity event

items.title: DE.AE - Anomalies and Events
items.description: Anomalous activity is detected and the potential impact of events is understood
questions: Is a baseline of network operations established?
Are detected events analyzed?
Is event data collected and correlated?

items.title: DE.AE-1: A baseline of network operations is established and managed
DE.AE-2: Detected events are analyzed to understand attack targets and methods
DE.AE-3: Event data are collected and correlated from multiple sources
DE.AE-4: Impact of events is determined
DE.AE-5: Incident alert thresholds are established
DE.CM - Security Continuous Monitoring
items.description: The information system and assets are monitored to identify cybersecurity events and verify effectiveness of protective measures
questions: Is the network monitored to detect potential cybersecurity events?
Is the physical environment monitored?
Are vulnerability scans performed?

items.title: DE.CM-1: The network is monitored to detect potential cybersecurity events
DE.CM-2: The physical environment is monitored to detect potential events
DE.CM-3: Personnel activity is monitored to detect potential events
DE.CM-4: Malicious code is detected
DE.CM-5: Unauthorized mobile code is detected

structure.title: RESPOND (RS)
structure.description: Develop and implement appropriate activities to take action regarding a detected cybersecurity incident

items.title: RS.RP - Response Planning
items.description: Response processes and procedures are executed and maintained
questions: Is there a response plan that is executed during or after an incident?
Are response plans tested?

items.title: RS.RP-1: Response plan is executed during or after an incident
RS.CO - Communications
items.description: Response activities are coordinated with internal and external stakeholders
questions: Do personnel know their roles and order of operations during response?
Are events reported consistent with established criteria?
Is information shared consistent with response plans?

items.title: RS.CO-1: Personnel know their roles and order of operations
RS.CO-2: Incidents are reported consistent with established criteria
RS.CO-3: Information is shared consistent with response plans
RS.CO-4: Coordination with stakeholders occurs consistent with response plans
RS.CO-5: Voluntary information sharing occurs with external stakeholders

structure.title: RECOVER (RC)
structure.description: Develop and implement appropriate activities to maintain plans for resilience and to restore capabilities or services impaired due to a cybersecurity incident

items.title: RC.RP - Recovery Planning
items.description: Recovery processes and procedures are executed and maintained
questions: Is there a recovery plan that is executed during or after a cybersecurity incident?
Are recovery plans tested?

items.title: RC.RP-1: Recovery plan is executed during or after a cybersecurity incident
RC.IM - Improvements
items.description: Recovery planning and processes are improved by incorporating lessons learned
questions: Are recovery plans updated based on lessons learned?
Are recovery strategies updated?

items.title: RC.IM-1: Recovery plans incorporate lessons learned
RC.IM-2: Recovery strategies are updated
